entry.title: Inconsistent Foreign Key naming in Blanket Agreements (OOAT - OAT1) tables
entry.content: hi experts, I have a question regarding the table structure of the Blanket Agreement (Contract) in SAP Business One. I've observed an inconsistency in the foreign key naming between the header and detail tables, which is different from other business documents in the system. The header table [OOAT] uses AbsId (Integer) as its Primary Key. The detail table [OAT1] uses AgrNo (Integer) as the Foreign Key, which points to [@OAGR].AbsId. hi experts, In all other major documents (e.g., Sales Order ORDR/RDR1, Invoice OINV/INV1), the header and detail tables use the same field name ( DocEntry) for the primary and foreign key relationship. My Question: What is the historical or design reason behind this naming inconsistency specifically for the Blanket Agreement tables? Why is the foreign key in [OAT1] named AgrNo instead of AbsId to match the header table? This seems to be a unique case, as other master data like Business Partner (OCRD) and Items (OITM) also use consistent names (CardCode, ItemCode) between their header and child tables. I have verified the relationship with an SQL query, which confirms the join is ON [OOAT].AbsId = [OAT1].AgrNo. Any insights into this design decision would be greatly appreciated. Thank you!

entry.title: Re: Show percentage of row totals in story report
entry.content:
Hello jo21,

The only way I can imagine right now, is to create separate calculated measures. So instead of putting the Overall Performance (or Potential) Rating Description into the columns of the cross-tab table, you can create one  restricted measure for each of them. In another calculated measure you can now sum these values up to get the subtotal. And each of the %-columns can now be calculated by the number per Rating  divided by the subtotal column.

I understand if this is not the best idea in case you have a lot of values in the columns, but in your case there are only 3, which means 7 calculated measures can cover your request.

entry.title: Re: COC Operation: Revaluation of COGS vs. Scrapping Fini...
entry.content:
You have configured 71201000 for COGS (VAX/VAY) and also for COC (revaluation). You have activated COGS split for that account. For scrapping (GBB-VNG), you use 71200000. During CKMLCP (actual costing), price differences are revaluated via COC. This causes COGS split logic to apply even for scrapping, which is incorrect.

To distinguish revaluation postings for sales (COGS) and scrapping (cost center consumption) under operation COC in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, you should use valuation modifier or account grouping to differentiate the account determination logicâ€”even though only one account can be assigned per valuation category and transaction key.

entry.title: Inconsistent Foreign Key naming in Service Contract (OOAT - OAT1) tables
entry.content: hi experts, I have a question regarding the table structure of the Blanket Agreement (Contract) in SAP Business One. I've observed an inconsistency in the foreign key naming between the header and detail tables, which is different from other business documents in the system. The header table [OOAT] uses AbsId (Integer) as its Primary Key. The detail table [OAT1] uses AgrNo (Integer) as the Foreign Key, which points to [@OAGR].AbsId. In all other major documents (e.g., Sales Order ORDR/RDR1, Invoice OINV/INV1), the header and detail tables use the same field name ( DocEntry) for the primary and foreign key relationship. My Question: What is the historical or design reason behind this naming inconsistency specifically for the Blanket Agreement tables? Why is the foreign key in [OAT1] named AgrNo instead of AbsId to match the header table? This seems to be a unique case, as other master data like Business Partner (OCRD) and Items (OITM) also use consistent names (CardCode, ItemCode) between their header and child tables. I have verified the relationship with an SQL query, which confirms the join is ON [OOAT].AbsId = [OAT1].AgrNo. Any insights into this design decision would be greatly appreciated. Thank you!

entry.title: Re: Building a position report and wish to see only the l...
entry.content:
Hi,

there is a KBA how to get the latest record 3505244 - How to fetch latest record in Story report? - SAP for Me. The example is based on education, but I have used it to get the latest record for the position object already. In your example the "Last Modified Date" has to be used instead of the "End Date".

Please also note that you have to remove the date filter in general, because we don't know which record was changed most recently. And removing the date filter normally returns a lot of data. So dependent on the amount of records you will get, the report will be very slow.

entry.title: using BAPI_PO_CHANGE to change the Delivery date schedule delivery date and validity end date
entry.content: While using BAPI_PO_CHANGE to change the deliverydate, schedule delivery date and Validity end date for a PO, The release strategy related fields are set to blocked when earlier it was fully released. And when released only from buyer, I'm getting authorization workflow is in progress error and the data is not changed. Is there a way to bypass this release reset logic so that the release related fields won't be changed when I make changes in the delivery dates?

entry.title: ğŸ“¢ Survey: ABAP Naming Conventions
entry.content:
How should a holistic naming convention store look?

Names are everywhere!

Most customers have specific naming conventions for their development artifacts. Many customers have them in rule books or use ATC to check them, by using the well-known ATC check for naming conventions.

Naming Convention ATC Check

The existing ATC check is very limited, though, as it has no broad coverage of CDS.

Today, we also have new requirements through the use of AI and Generators. When using Joule for Developers, for example, customers expect that their naming conventions are automatically applied. This also holds true when using generators like the RAP generator. 

But how would you expect a naming convention store to look?

1. Option: A central naming convention store

This could be a Fiori app in a central system where the naming conventions are stored. These can then be maintained globally. The ATC check and different tools like generators and AI could connect to that system.

Pros:
   - central maintenance, probably by a central team
   - central excemption process and governance
Cons:
   - Differing rules, according to package and/or system, would be difficult to model
   - The check would come quite late in the development process, i.e. no check by the compiler
   - Excemptions create organizational overhead 


2. Option: Naming convention as source artifact

Store the naming convention as part of the source code, referencing the package and its subpackages.

Pros:
  - Naming convention near the source code, which could even be checked by the compiler
  - Excemptions could be handled locally in the naming convention
 Cons:
  - No central maintenance, probably much more effort to maintain
  - No central governance

The answer probably also depends upon which persona maintains such a naming convention in your company. Is it some central architect or governance team or just the developers?

What do you think?

I am happy to hear your thoughts in the comments. You can also vote for the comments of others.

Disclaimer: this blog post does not imply that SAP will build any product related to naming conventions in the future.

entry.title: SAP PaPM Cloud Standard Model: Whatâ€™s New as of 2025-11-03?
entry.content:
Welcome to the latest update of our SAP Profitability and Performance Management Cloud (SAP PaPM Cloud) Standard Model Whatâ€™s New series! With this update, weâ€™re excited to introduce enhancements that make managing environments, customizing templates, and monitoring subscription usage more seamless and transparent. 

From advanced metering logic for subscription plans, to support for custom fields in SD and PO functions, and even push notifications for private environment changes, these updates are designed to improve collaboration, flexibility, and operational insights. Letâ€™s dive into whatâ€™s new and how these features can help you optimize your processes. 

Letâ€™s take a look at the newest update of SAP PaPM Cloud Standard Model! 

Administration | Settings

Subscription Metering Data Settings

SAP PaPM Cloud Standard Model now provides enhanced metering capabilities for Runtime DB and BYOD plans. Key features include:

  • Monthly Peak Tracking: System exposes the highest usage value each month with peak occurrence dates
  • Reports: Downloadable historical peak usage reports for both Runtime DB (Capacity Units) and BYOD (GB)
  • UI Integration: View current peak values directly in the Administration Settings screen

For Default/tandd plan (measured in CU):

For BYOD plan (measured in GB):

For more information, see Subscription Metering Data Settings in our Application Help on SAP Help Portal.

Modeling Settings: Customize RFA Template

In our previous Whatâ€™s New blog post, we introduced the ability to create custom fields for Finance Accounts Payable, Finance Accounts Payable Items, Finance Accounts Receivable, and Finance Accounts Receivable Items.

Great news! Weâ€™ve now added two more RFA types:

  • Sales and Distribution
  • Purchase Order

This enhancement gives you even more flexibility to tailor your integration scenarios and align with your unique business requirements.

For more details, visit the Help Portal â€“ Modeling Settings.

Environment Screen | Main

Push Notifications

An enhancement for SAP PaPM Cloud Standard Model: Extended Environment Access Level Functionality is now available in your tenants. Now when an administrator creates, edits, copies, and deletes a private environment, the users assigned to authorized teams will get an in-app and email notifications about these actions. See sample image below:

Thatâ€™s a wrap for this quarterâ€™s updates! With these new capabilities, SAP PaPM Cloud Standard Model continues to evolve to meet your business needs.

Stay tuned for more innovations in the coming releases, and donâ€™t forget to explore the detailed documentation in the SAP Help Portal for deeper insights.

entry.title: CAP backend service through BTP configured Destination
entry.content:
Dear all,

We are writing to request assistance with a configuration issue on our SAP BTP Cloud Foundry environment. We are encountering a consistent 500 Internal Server Error when our SAPUI5 application attempts to call a CAP backend service through a configured Destination.

System Architecture:

  • Frontend: A SAPUI5 application (UI5 version 1.140.0) deployed on SAP BTP.

  • Backend: An SAP Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP) application deployed as a back-end service on the same BTP CF space.

  • Connectivity: The frontend connects to the backend via a BTP Destination named EINV_CAP_BackEnd_SRV.

  • Authentication: The connection is secured using OAuth2ClientCredentials flow with an XSUAA service instance as shown below:

 

 

Problem Description:
When the frontend application makes a call to the OData service endpoint (/odata/v4/catalg/), the request fails with a 500 Internal Server Error.

 



 

Troubleshooting Steps and Findings:
We have performed several tests to isolate the issue, and here is what we have confirmed:

  1. The CAP Backend Service is Working: If we call the CAP service endpoint directly using Postman and provide a manually obtained Bearer Token, we receive a 200 OK response with the expected data. This confirms that the service logic is correct.

  2. The BTP Destination is Working: We have successfully tested the EINV_CAP_BackEnd_SRV destination using the BTP Cockpit's "Check Connection" feature and also by calling the Destination Service API via Postman. In both cases, the destination successfully fetches a valid JWT Bearer Token from the XSUAA service. Here below the evidences:

     




  1. Authentication Flow Seems Partially Correct: We are not receiving 401 Unauthorized or 403 Forbidden errors.

Based on these findings, we believe the issue lies in the interaction between the Approuter, the Destination Service, and the CAP service's security validation.

Configuration Details:

  • Destination: EINV_CAP_BackEnd_SRV

    • Type: HTTP

    • URL: https://d03-e-invoice01-cf01-d03-e-invoice01-cf01-sp01-fatturaz2a9200d4.cfapps.eu10-004.hana.ondemand.com/

    • Proxy Type: Internet

    • Authentication: OAuth2ClientCredentials

    • Client ID: sb-FatturazioneElettronicaAttiva!t566124

    • Token Service URL: https://d03-e-invoice01.authentication.eu10.hana.ondemand.com/oauth/token

  • xs-app.json Route Configuration:

codeJSON

{

"source": "^/odata/v4/catalg/(.*)$",

"target": "/odata/v4/catalg/$1",

"destination": "EINV_CAP_BackEnd_SRV",

"authenticationType": "xsuaa",

"csrfProtection": false

}

 



  • manifest.json DataSource Configuration:

codeJSON

"dataSources": {

"capSrv": {

"uri": "/odata/v4/catalg/",

"type": "OData",

"settings": {

"odataVersion": "4.0"

}

}

}

 



Could someone please assist us in identifying the cause of this 500 error? Any guidance on how to further debug this or what might be misconfigured would be greatly appreciated.

Thank you for your time

entry.title: Re: Query Regarding Automatic Quantity Change in Asset Cards
entry.content:
Hi,

Unlike before in previous SAP Products, the current version of Asset Accounting, so called IAA " Intelligent Asset Accounting" handles things differently. With respect to quantity, it is not managed anymore on asset master record. Asset master just stores the unit of measurement and then if this UOM matches the UOM of the line item to be posted, it will be considered for quantity changes, that happen per ledger. Obviously, the quantity is not stored anywhere in asset but it is calculated on the flay. So, no simple adjustment can be done; no quantity change without a posting!

Best regards, Mick

entry.title: Re: Display measure name with selected variable/prompt value
entry.content:
Hi @deshmukh ,

Kindly try testing the below workaround in your SAC story.

Create a restricted measure in your story with the required measure and date dimesion( below i have taken Fiscal Year of Ledger). 

New Calculation Input Control 'year2' is created for Dimension ' Fiscal Year of Ledger' . 

In the description of the restricted measure , enter the Amount followed by name of the input control created above from the dropdown.

Use this restricted measure in your story instead of the original measure and you can change the value of the input control using the below script(can be added to an event) based on the selected variable value by the user. 

Input control can be hidden during the runtime.

//getting the variable value selected by the user
var year = Table_1.getDataSource().getVariableValues("!CDS_F_2CN0E2PMNHTZPHA0EDX597")[0];
console.log(year.type);

var passyear = cast(Type.SingleVariableValue,year);
var p_year = "K4"+ passyear.value;

//passing the values to the calculation input control year2
year2.getInputControlDataSource().setSelectedMembers(p_year);

Output

Best Regards,

Shivam

entry.title: Secure By Default: SAP S/4HANA 2025 â€“ The Security Journey Continues
entry.content:
What began as a bold initiative to strengthen the default security posture of SAP S/4HANA has, over the years, evolved into a core principle of the product. While the journey from concept to execution took time, weâ€™ve now reached a point where Secure By Default is not just an aspiration - itâ€™s a continuously expanding reality. With each release, more robust security settings are seamlessly integrated, helping customers benefit from enhanced protection without additional effort.

With the release of SAP S/4HANA 2025, also named SAP Cloud ERP Private 2025,  another step was taken by SAP S/4HANA supported by ABAP Platform to cover some additional topics for new installations, conversions, and system copies.

Identical to the former years, Secure By Default settings are applied for

    • SAP S/4HANA 2025 / SAP Cloud ERP Private 2025
    • All SAP products based on S/4HANA Foundation 2025

List of new Secure By Default Settings

In new installations, system copies, and conversions the following security relevant settings and configurations are applied automatically:

    • Add support for TLS1.3 for web-based interfaces of SAP S/4HANA in addition to TLS1.2
    • Adjust the security log of ICM to make it machine-readable for easier integration into SIEM solutions
    • Disable support for SAP logon tickets while still accepting SAP Assertion Tickets
    • Configure a Report-only Content Security Policy (CSP) for faster introduction of a Content Security Policy as second level of defence for S/4HANA
    • Disable the outdated ICM content scan interface as dedicated checks have been introduced in browser-based applications against Cross Site Scripting (XSS) and input validation.

Additional Information

As with SAP S/4HANA 1909, SAP S/4HANA 2020, SAP S/4HANA 2021, SAP S/4HANA 2023 customers will receive the security settings automatically with new installations, system copies and conversions. An opt-out is possible for the security relevant profile parameters but not recommended from SAP side. More details can be found in SAP Note 2926224.

As Secure By Default settings cannot and will not cover all aspects of security settings in S/4HANA systems, we highly recommend customers to perform additional reviews and improvements of their security settings. Good sources are the SAP security whitepapers. Secure by Default settings provide a good starting point, but there are additional security settings and configurations which are either customer specific, cannot be shipped as default or need to be applied on a regular basis (e.g., security patching).

    • Use the SAP-provided tools and services, such as Early Watch Alert, Configuration Validation and System Recommendations in order to display missing security patches. These inform you about gaps in a cost-efficient way.
    • Always introduce disruptive security settings with good timing. Conversion projects and new installations are opportunities to increase security. As a benefit, security testing can be included as part of the testing activities planned within the project. This leverages synergies in the area that has proven to be particularly costly.

Please refer to these blog posts for older SAP S/4HANA releases

    • For SAP S/4HANA 2023 â€“ Secure By Default, please also refer to this blog https://blogs.sap.com/2023/10/18/another-chapter-of-secure-by-default-for-sap-s-4hana-2023/
    • For SAP S/4HANA 2022 â€“ Secure By Default, please also refer to this blog https://blogs.sap.com/2022/11/03/secure-by-default-returns-with-sap-s-4hana-2022
    • For SAP S/4HANA 2021 â€“ Secure By Default, please also refer to this blog The story resumes â€“ Secure By Default for SAP S/4HANA 2021
    • For SAP S/4HANA 2020 â€“ Secure By Default, please also refer to this blog Secure By Default for SAP S/4HANA 2020
    • For SAP S/4HANA 1909 â€“ Secure By Default, please also refer to this blog Secure By Default: Ways To Harden Your Systems At (Almost) No Cost

Complete List of all SAP S/4HANA Secure By Default Settings

Below you can find a complete list of all Secure By Default settings that are included in SAP S/4HANA 2025. Bold entries were added with SAP S/4HANA 2025:

    • Security relevant profile parameters are set to secure values which increases security in areas such as:
        • Mandatory SSL Protection of session logon tickets (part of S/4HANA 2022)
        • Disable support for SAP logon tickets while still accepting SAP Assertion Tickets (part of S/4HANA 2025)
        • Protect the RFC gateway against unauthorized RFC call forwarding (part of S/4HANA 2022)
        • Strong password policies and password hashes (part of S/4HANA 2020)
        • Protection of internal system communication (part of S/4HANA 2020)
        • Strengthened authorizations system (part of S/4HANA 1909)
        • Enhanced RFC interface protection (part of S/4HANA 1909)
        • Enforce TLS1.2-only for web-based interfaces of SAP S/4HANA covering SAP Internet Communication Manager (ICM), SAP Start Service, SAP Host Agent (part of S/4HANA 2022)
        • Add support for TLS1.3 for web-based interfaces of SAP S/4HANA in addition to TLS1.2 (part of S/4HANA 2025)
        • Disable the old insecure tickets for trusted / trusting communication (part of S/4HANA 2023)
        • Disable the outdated ICM content scan interface as dedicated checks have been introduced in the browser-based applications against Cross Site Scripting (XSS) and input validation (part of S/4HANA 2025)
    • Security relevant configurations and customizing are set to secure values
        • Prevent usage of non-reference user as reference user (part of S/4HANA 2022)
        • 3 parameters were changed to secure defaults in the Transport Management (part of S/4HANA 2021)
        • Web protection is increased by activation of the UCON HTTP allowlist (part of S/4HANA 2021)
        • Start authorizations for WebDynpro were enabled for an improved security for Webdynpro applications (part of S/4HANA 2021)
        • All available scenarios of the Switchable Authorization Framework (SACF) are activated which adds additional functional authorization checks for technical function modules (part of S/4HANA 2020)
        • All available scenarios of the Generic Application Access Rules (SLDW) were activated as defined by SAP development (part of S/4HANA 2021)
        • Prevent the assignment of users to roles as part of transports to avoid that users get authorizations in higher tiers while importing transports (part of S/4HANA 2023)
    • Security relevant logging was enabled to support traceability and security monitoring
        • Performance, usability and analysis optimized log of RFC and SICF usage to support deactivation of unused RFC function modules and SICF services (part of S/4HANA 2022 and S/4HANA 2023)
        • Security Audit Log is activated what allows customers to trace critical activities in the system (part of S/4HANA 1909)
        • Activation of table logging for business-critical tables (part of S/4HANA 2021)
        • HTTP server and HTTP client log of the SAP Internet Communication Manager is enabled (part of S/4HANA 1909)
        • Granular logging of Secure By Default activations in application log for easier debugging in conversions (part of S/4HANA 2023)
        • Adjust the security log of ICM to make it machine-readable for easier integration into SIEM solutions (part of S/4HANA 2025)
        • Configure a Report-only Content Security Policy (CSP) for faster introduction of a Content Security Policy as second level of defence for S/4HANA (part of S/4HANA 2025)
    • HANA for S/4HANA relevant configurations were enabled to improve traceability and encryption
        • SAP HANA Audit Log is switched on for HANAs running SAP S/4HANA. This enables traceability of activities on SAP HANA database level (part of S/4HANA 2021)
        • Leverage the automated activation of HANA Data at Rest Encryption Features as part of HANA2 SP07 installations to ensure that business data cannot be accessed on file system level (part of S/4HANA 2023)
    • Values of additional security relevant profile parameters were changed in the kernel default

entry.title: Joule enablement process blog - How to get started with Joule in Ariba
entry.content:
Hi there and welcome to my blog. 

My name is Filiz Yasar, I am one of the Solution Value Advisors based in the Netherlands.  The world of procurement is continuously evolving, and with it are the tools and technologies aimed at optimizing organizational spend.  Here, I am excited to present my blog on how artificial intelligence can elevate the user experience in SAP Ariba.

By following these steps and ensuring all prerequisites are met, you can effectively get started with Joule in SAP Ariba applications, enhancing your operational efficiency through AI-powered interactions.

Prerequisites

    • Ensure you have a license for one or more SAP Ariba applications (Guided Buying, Guided Sourcing, Supplier Management) in a supported data center. The currently supported data centers are listed here.
    • You need an enterprise global account on SAP BTP. Joule leverages BTP to simplify complex integration landscapes.
    • Integrate the SAP Ariba application with Identity Authentication as Joule leverages the Identity Authentication Service (IAS) setup.
    • Configure the navigation service of SAP Build Work Zone to support navigation to different applications from Joule and handle role-based access scenarios.
    • Create a subaccount in your global account using the SAP BTP cockpit for provisioning Joule.

Steps to Activate Joule

    • Enable either the Joule Base SKU (8019544) or the Joule Premium SKU (8019164) from the SAP Store.
    • Ensure the necessary BTP services are setup and configured, including:
      • SAP Cloud Identity Services for seamless SSO experience. (Refer this blog for details on SAP Ariba SSO with SAP Cloud Identity Services).
      • SAP Build Work Zone for navigation and role-based access.

Available Features

    • Provides knowledge-based results from SAP applications, such as SAP Help Documentation.
    • Document Grounding allows uploading customer-owned content for FAQs and policies.
    • Navigate SAP applications using natural language queries.
    • Open applications in new browser tabs with conversation history.
    • Direct entry point to backend systems for tasks like purchase order approvals, job positions creation, etc.

 

Available Skills

  • Guided Buying:
    • Transactional: Get status of purchase requisition, show recent PRs, show approvers of PR, etc.
    • Navigational: View requisition.
  • Guided Sourcing:
    • Transactional: List sourcing events, return RFx status, send reminder emails, etc.
    • Navigational: Go to My Tasks, Go to Sourcing Event.
  • Supplier Management:
    • Transactional: Show primary contact information of supplier, list suppliers in registration/invited status.
  • Multi-Language Support
  • Joule supports multiple languages, including English, German, French, Spanish, Portuguese, Japanese, Korean, Chinese, Vietnamese, Greek, and Polish.

Costing

  • All the mentioned Joule skills are part of Joule base and will not be charged any AI units.

 

Limitations (as of Q3 2025 Release)

  • Multi-ERP Setup Issue:
    • Joule does not currently support multi-tenant consolidation. Run Joule Booster in every child realm to overcome this limitation.

For more information on setting up Joule please look at our setup Guide.

Thank you for reading my blog!

entry.title: Re: Add screen text field dynamically
entry.content:
Hi Sandra

Actually it is MB1A that is obsolete (OSS note 2210569). Step loop is a bit dusty old technique, but I'm almost sure it is not totally obsolete.

I am still using step-loop for RF transactions running via webgui on android scanners. In this scenarios table control and ALV are not useful alternatives.

In general I agree that the functionality to dynamically add a line to a table on screen can also be made with table controls or ALV. The 3 options has each their own look and feel.

@jeff_broodwar if you want to use the same technique as MB1A, then you should search for ABAP step loop. You will find plenty of documentation online. Most of what you find will be around 20 years old, but it should still work.
I found Step-Loops in Module Pool Programming | PDF | Screenshot | Computer Science . This seems to explain it in a good way, but this site requires login.

There is also a little SAP standard documentation:
Step Loop 
Creating a step loop in screen painter 

Best Regards
Thomas Madsen Nielsen

entry.title: SAP TM - Managing CDHDR and CDPOS Tables for /SCMTMS/CD_TOR Objects in SAP TM
entry.content:
SAP TM - Managing CDHDR and CDPOS Tables for /SCMTMS/CD_TOR Objects in SAP TM

As mentioned in my previous Blog How to enable logs in SAP TM - SAP Community some of the logs in TM is activated separate. Example if you would Activate Change Documents for Locations or Trade Lane changes:

This Log will also reflect in the standard table for Logs changes.

Overview

The CDHDR (Change Document Header) and CDPOS (Change Document Items) tables are critical components in SAP Transportation Management for tracking changes to business objects. These tables can experience significant growth due to the high volume of transportation-related transactions and updates, requiring proactive management to maintain system performance

The /SCMTMS/CD_TOR change document object is the primary object for Transportation Orders and related documents in SAP TM, tracking changes to freight orders, transportation requirements, and other TM business documents High volumes of change documents in CDPOS for /SCMTMS/CD_TOR objects can significantly impact system performance and require careful management strategies.

In the transaction S_ALR_87101225 - Cust. Tables without Log you can see the table if are active for record the log or not. Example table below for Charge Item

Also, you can display the statistics linked to the  Managing CDHDR and CDPOS 

Table Structure and Relationships

CDHDR (Change Document Header)

  • CHANGENR: Change document number (automatically assigned) that uniquely identifies each change document
  • OBJECTCLAS: Object class (e.g., /SCMTMS/CD_TOR for TM objects) that categorizes the type of business object being tracked
  • OBJECTID: Document number of the changed object, containing the transportation order identification
  • UDATE/UTIME: Change date and time stamps that record when modifications occurred
  • USERNAME: User who made the change, providing audit trail information

CDPOS (Change Document Items)

  • CHANGENR: Links to CDHDR change document number, establishing the relationship between header and items
  • TABNAME: Table name where change occurred, identifying specific TM database tables
  • TABKEY: Key of the changed table record, containing the transportation order key structure
  • FNAME: Field name that was changed, specifying which data element was modified
  • VALUE_OLD/VALUE_NEW: Old and new field values, capturing the actual data changes
  • CHNGIND: Change indicator (U=Update, I=Insert, D=Delete) showing the type of modification

/SCMTMS/CD_TOR Object Specifics

Covered Business Objects

  • Transportation Orders (TOR) and their associated nodes
  • Freight Orders with all related planning and execution data
  • Transportation Requirements (both order-based and delivery-based)
  • Related TM documents including freight bookings and forwarding orders

Change Triggers

  • Document status changes throughout the transportation lifecycle
  • Planning modifications including route and scheduling updates
  • Cost updates from charge calculations and freight settlements
  • Route changes and transportation execution modifications

Data Volume Management Strategies

Growth Analysis

The number of records in CDHDR and CDPOS tables can grow rapidly due to frequent transportation-related transactions. Volume estimation should consider the frequency of charge calculations, status updates, and planning modifications Growth rate calculations should account for batch jobs that trigger charge calculations, as these can generate significant change document volumes.

In the Table we can see the TM objects which are having the changes records also the refer tables:

Archiving Approach

Change documents are archived together with business documents, but you can archive just the change documents via transaction SARA with archiving object CHANGEDOCU For "Change doc. object" you can set "/SCMTMS/CD_TOR" for the records related to the objects and then specify the "From" and "To" date accordingly to consider the relevant records only. Note that archived change documents are not displayed on the UI of the business documents anymore

Configuration Steps

Change Document Activation

  1. Transaction Codes: Use transaction S_ALR_87101225 to check and activate change document logging for specific tables
  2. Object-specific Settings: Configure change document settings in TM customizing to control which objects and fields generate change documents
  3. Field-level Configuration: Use the "Track Changes" setting in document customizing to avoid unnecessary change document creation
  4. Customizing Path Navigation: Access settings through Cross-Application Components â†’ Processes and Tools for Enterprise Applications â†’ Reusable Objects and Functions for BOPF Environment

Archiving Setup

  1. SARA Transaction Configuration: Configure archiving using transaction SARA with archiving object CHANGEDOCU for change documents specifically
  2. CHANGEDOCU Object Parameters: Set "Change doc. object" to "/SCMTMS/CD_TOR" and specify appropriate date ranges
  3. Selection Variant Creation: Define selection criteria based on creation dates and document types
  4. Job Scheduling Setup: Schedule archiving jobs during low-activity periods and consider parallel processing for large volumes

Performance Optimization

Database Considerations

  • Index Optimization: Ensure proper indexing on CHANGENR, OBJECTCLAS, OBJECTID, and UDATE fields
  • Partitioning Recommendations: Consider database partitioning for very large installations
  • Query Performance Tuning: Use FOR ALL ENTRIES efficiently when querying these tables

System Impact Mitigation

  • Memory Management: Large change document volumes can cause memory allocation issues during archiving operations
  • I/O Optimization: High table growth impacts overall system I/O performance
  • Background Processing: Coordinate change document archiving with other system maintenance activities

Monitoring and Maintenance

Regular Checks

  • Table Size Monitoring: Use transaction DB02 or SAP S/4HANA sizing reports to identify when CDHDR and CDPOS become among the largest tables in the system
  • Growth Rate Tracking: Implement regular monitoring using recommendations from SAP Note 2388483 for technical table management
  • Performance Impact Assessment: Monitor for slow transaction performance when accessing business documents with change history

Maintenance Activities

  1. Statistics Updates: Ensure database statistics are regularly updated, especially after large archiving operations
  2. Index Maintenance: Rebuild database indexes after archiving operations
  3. Archive Validation: Verify successful archiving and deletion processes
  4. Cleanup Procedures: Use report /SCMTMS/CLEANUP_CDPOS only for fixing inconsistencies related to text collections

Troubleshooting Common Issues

High Volume Growth

  • Symptoms: Excessive records in CDPOS for /SCMTMS/CD_TOR objects causing performance degradation
  • Root Causes: Unnecessary change document creation due to misconfigured "Track Changes" settings
  • Resolution Steps:
    1. Immediate Actions: Check for which TM documents change documents are required and avoid unnecessary creation
    2. Long-term Solutions: Implement proper archiving strategy and review change document activation settings

Performance Problems

  • Symptoms: System slowdown when accessing transportation documents with change history
  • Diagnosis: Monitor table growth and analyze change document creation patterns
  • Resolution Steps:
    1. Quick Fixes: Archive old change documents and optimize database statistics
    2. Permanent Solutions: Reduce frequency of batch jobs that trigger charge calculations

Best Practices

Configuration Guidelines

  • Archive change documents using archiving object CHANGEDOCU or with application archiving objects
  • Check which TM documents require change documents and avoid unnecessary creation using the general "Track Changes" setting
  • Reduce the frequency of batch jobs that call charge calculation or adjust selection criteria

Operational Procedures

  • Monitor CDPOS table regularly to maintain controlled data volumes
  • Implement SAP Notes 2985558, 3035027, and 3190620 for change document improvements
  • Schedule archiving during low-activity periods with appropriate commit counters

Related Tools and Transactions

Transaction

Purpose

Usage Context

SARA

Archive Administration

Change document archiving setup and execution

S_ALR_87101225

Table Information

Check change document activation status

SCU3

Table Logging

View change history for tables

RSCDOK99

Delete Change Documents

Direct deletion (not recommended)

ST12

Performance Trace

Analyze performance issues

Implementation Checklist

Pre-Implementation

  • Analyze current CDHDR and CDPOS table sizes and growth rates
  • Review existing change document configuration for /SCMTMS/CD_TOR objects
  • Assess performance impact and system requirements

A BadI  /SCMTMS/BADI_GEN_CDO_CONTROL provides control over change document generation for Transportation Management business objects:

BADi Implementation Guide: /SCMTMS/BADI_GEN_CDO_CONTROL

  • Used in the Basic Functions (TM-BF) component to activate or deactivate change document writing
  • Enables document-specific control where standard document type differentiation is not available

BADi Details

  • BADi Name: /SCMTMS/BADI_GEN_CDO_CONTROL
  • Enhancement Spot: /SCMTMS/GEN_CDO_CTRL
  • Interface: /SCMTMS/IF_EX_GEN_CDO_CONTROL
  • Usage: Multiple use (all active implementations are called)

Methods Available

Method Name

Purpose

Parameters

Return Type

CHECK_CDO_IS_ACTIVE

Determines if change documents should be written for specific business objects

Business object type, instance data

Boolean flag

Implementation Steps

  1. Access SE18 (BADi Builder) or SE80/ADT for enhancement implementation
  2. Create enhancement implementation for /SCMTMS/BADI_GEN_CDO_CONTROL
  3. Create BADi implementation class inheriting from /SCMTMS/IF_EX_GEN_CDO_CONTROL
  4. Implement CHECK_CDO_IS_ACTIVE method with business logic
  5. Activate the implementation and assign to development package
  6. Test change document generation behavior

Code Structure Template

Check Attachement in the Oss Note: 2026544 - How to write change documents only for certain BO nodes - SAP for Me

Use Cases

  • Control change document creation for freight units and freight orders
  • Implement business-specific rules for change tracking
  • Optimize system performance by selective change document generation
  • Support compliance requirements for audit trails

Configuration Requirements

  • Change document handling must be activated in Customizing under Transportation Management â†’ Master Data â†’ Transportation Network
  • Proper authorization for enhancement implementation
  • Development package assignment for transport management

Testing Approach

  • Create/modify TM business objects (freight orders, freight units)
  • Verify change documents are created/suppressed based on implementation logic
  • Test with different business object types and scenarios
  • Validate performance impact in high-volume environments

Common Issues & Solutions

Issue

Cause

Resolution

Change documents not generated

BADi returns false for all cases

Review implementation logic and ensure proper conditions

Performance degradation

Complex logic in CHECK_CDO_IS_ACTIVE

Optimize method implementation and use efficient checks

Multiple implementations conflict

Different BADi implementations return conflicting results

Coordinate implementation logic across multiple BADis

Related Objects

  • Enhancement Spot: /SCMTMS/GEN_CDO_CTRL
  • Change document objects for TM business objects
  • Transportation Management master data configuration
  • Business Object Processing Framework (BOBF) for TM objects

Post-Implementation

  • Monitor archiving job performance and success rates
  • Validate that archived change documents are no longer displayed in business document UIs
  • Establish regular monitoring and maintenance schedules

Support documentation for this topic

3360479 - Best practices in CDPOS for /SCMTMS/CD_TOR objects - SAP for Me

2388483 - How-To: Data Management for Technical Tables - SAP for Me

Hope this support you.

Kind regards

Rogerio Lima.

entry.title: Cutting Through the AI Hype: Whatâ€™s the Real Business Impact?
entry.content:
Businesses around the world are investing heavily in artificial intelligence â€“ but where does the investment deliver real value, and where do gaps remain? To research this question, SAP partnered with Oxford Economics, a leading global economic advisory and research firm.

â€‹â€œWe commissioned this research to help enterprises cut through the hype, understand AIâ€™s real business impact, and accelerate their own measurable outcomes,â€ said Brenda Bown, Chief Marketing Officer of Business AI at SAP.

The study surveyed 1,600 senior executives across eight global markets: Australia, Brazil, China, Germany, India, Singapore, the United Kingdom, and the United States. The survey was conducted between July and August 2025.

Here are the five key findings from the study:  

1. AI plays a key role in global business operations

The study found that businesses are making significant AI investments across various functions, aiming to achieve positive returns. Participants reported that AI already supports 25% of their organizationsâ€™ business tasks globally, with expectations for that figure to rise to 41% within two years. Most respondents indicated they are scaling AI automation and experimenting with generative AI, while very few said they had no plans to adopt either technology.

Despite challenges to broader implementation, 63% of businesses said they are finding solutions and continuing to make progress. Only 3% believe AI will never become central to business processes, decision-making, or customer offerings. A majority (59%) reported that AI has helped them overcome key business challenges.

â€‹When asked how they prioritize AI investments, 44% described their approach as piecemeal, 32% said it was driven by individual departments, and 15% called it ad hoc. Only 9% of businesses are investing based on a strategic, holistic approach.

2. Businesses are seeing returns on AI investment

Respondents reported an average AI spend of over US$26 million per organization for the current fiscal year, with investment expected to grow by 37% over the next two years. Compared to other technologies, 49% agreed that AI initiatives deliver positive ROI more quickly.

Accordingly, AI investment is expected to drive ROI of 16% this year (an average of US$4.7 million), which is anticipated to nearly double in two yearsâ€™ time to 31% (US$12.3 million).

In fact, 79% of participants saw positive returns within one to three years, reinforcing optimism about AIâ€™s rapid impact. However, nearly two-thirds (65%) were either unsure or did not believe AI was delivering its full potential.

To maximize ROI, the top strategies cited were aligning AI initiatives with business strategy and ensuring the availability and quality of data. These were followed by adopting best-of-breed AI platforms and solutions.

3. Lack of confidence in AI data readiness

The study found that while businesses recognize the importance of data in unlocking AIâ€™s potential, many lack confidence in their readiness to integrate it effectively. Many (71%) respondents said data is either very important or critical when making decisions about AI investments. However, a majority expressed doubts about their ability to responsibly share and integrate data across business functions (55%) or with external partners (60%).

Nearly two-thirds (64%) of businesses rated their overall data readiness as sufficient, yet they also identified legal, risk and compliance, finance, and HR as among the least data-ready areas â€“ often the most complex and sensitive when it comes to data.

When asked about the main challenges to data readiness, 75% cited incomplete or inconsistent data, followed by poor data quality (69%) and siloed data (68%).

4. Businesses are investing in talent to maximize AI impact

Organizations recognize that technology alone wonâ€™t deliver ROI, and believe that human judgment, creativity, and adoption behaviors are essential to unlocking AIâ€™s full potential. Equipping employees with the right skills and frameworks helps ensure AI enhances, rather than replaces, their contributions.

Nearly three-quarters (73%) of respondents said they are upskilling or reskilling current employees, and two-thirds (65%) are identifying roles likely to be augmented by AI. A majority (57%) reported redesigning jobs to support collaboration between humans and AI. However, many businesses believe their teams are not yet adequately prepared to use AI responsibly, citing a lack of comprehensive training and missing guardrails.

This gap is contributing to risky decision-making: 64% said employees are using unapproved â€œshadow AIâ€ tools at least occasionally, and 77% expressed concern about the risks. â€œShadow AIâ€ remains a major issue, with over half of companies reporting inaccurate outputs, and many noting data leaks or security vulnerabilities.

5. The future of AI is agentic

More than three-quarters of global businesses (78%) believe agentic AI has moderate to very high potential to transform their operations. (AI agents are capable of autonomous decision-making and task execution without constant human input.) The most anticipated benefits include automating processes, improving planning and decision-making, and boosting operational efficiency.

Despite this optimism, only 5% of the respondents say their businesses are fully prepared to deploy and scale AI agents, while 54% consider themselves partially prepared. To get ready for agentic AI, 63% of respondents have piloted agent-based use cases, and 56% are upskilling internal teams or recruiting new talent. Investment in agentic AI is expected to deliver a 10% ROI â€“ equivalent to US$4.3 million â€“ over the next two years.

However, only about half of the participants said agentic AI will significantly influence strategic planning in the near term, and that their organization has a clear, shared understanding of what agentic AI is and what it can do. To conclude, the study emphasizes that the opportunity for businesses lies not just in recognizing that thereâ€™s no turning back â€“ but in investing strategically in AI to unlock sustained and growing returns. As Brenda Bown put it: â€œThe findings show that when companies connect AI to quality data, invest in skills, and embed intelligence into core workflows, they generate meaningful returns on investment.â€

Note: This article was first published as Global News at SAP One: Cutting Through the AI Hype: Whatâ€™s the Real Business Impact?

entry.title: Re: Switch debug user via ADT shows popup /H_REACTIVATE_EXTD_DBG KIND=USER USER=SAP_WFRT
entry.content:
For information, I have found the SAP note 3616366 - Downport of command %_KEEPALIVE - SAP for Me which handles another special function code, %_KEEPALIVE, dedicated to transactions running in Fiori via SAP GUI for HTML, which is automatically triggered for all open sessions after 15 minutes (the default FLP timeout setting) to handle timeouts (*).

So, it's a little bit like the transactions running in Eclipse when the field command H_REACTIVATE_EXTD_DBG is sent to all of them.

The note does a fix of SAPMSSYD, the general-purpose system program common to all SAP GUI transactions, to handle %_KEEPALIVE and few other % system function codes. Below is the fix of SAPMSSYD. The part in the subroutine KEEP_ALIVE is not interesting, but there's DYNP_SET_STATUS field 4 and 45, maybe it "swallows" the function code after the processing logic, maybe RS_ADTDBG_ACTIVATE_BY_OKCODE could be triggered the same way as %_KEEPALIVE...

 

  elseif my_ucomm(11) = '%_KEEPALIVE'.
    perform keep_alive.
    call 'DYNP_SET_STATUS' id 'FUNCTION' field 4 id 'VALUE' field 1. "#EC CI_CCALL
    call 'DYNP_SET_STATUS' id 'FUNCTION' field 45 id 'VALUE' field 1. "#EC CI_CCALL

 

(*) NB: the symptom of the %_KEEPALIVE issue is described in the note 3642150 - SAP GUI for HTML: Support Of FLP's ExtendSession Service - SAP for Me.

entry.title: Standard Report for checking SoD Conflicts in SAP
entry.content:
Report for checking SoD Conflicts:
It is possible to use the standard report RSUSR008_009_NEW to set up a basic SoD analysis in
the SAP system (Figure 1). This below report is available from SAP_BASIS 740 to 758 ERP systems.
rsusr008_009_NEW

Figure 1: Report RSUSR008_009_NEW

 

With this report is it possible to get an overview of users/roles having access to critical
authorizations and/or critical combinations (SoD conflicts). By default this report comes with only one Critical Authorization variant 'SAP_RSUSR009' if you try to run this report with this default variant, then this report won't work as expected. 

Figure 2: Report RSUSR008_009_NEW Output

So, in order to get accurate results, you need to define the rule set first. The rule set contains critical authorizations and critical combinations. The critical authorizations must be defined. When this is done, you can define the critical combinations. 

Click on the 'New Entries' to create new Critical Authorization variant. This will trigger a Customizing TR and all the changes will be recorded under Cluster: VCUSRVAR

Now the custom Variant is created, but it's still missing the auth configuration or logics, which need to be added in the second folder named Authorization data.

Authorization Data folder only understands Auth ID. before proceeding further, you need to create a custom Auth ID.

Here is the process:

Now you need to make some changes in table USCRAUTHID. This is a standard table in SAP R/3 ERP systems.

 

By default, you canâ€™t make or add any entries with SE16, SM30 transactions. You need to execute 1 function module to add entries to this table.

Go to Transaction: SE37

 

Now select Function Module: SE16N_INTERFACE

 

Now put the table name (USCRAUTHID) in the parameter â€˜I_TABâ€™ and put â€˜Xâ€™ in I_EDIT section and hit Execute.

 

After executing, you can add or modify entries to the table USCRAUTHID. Now click on Append Row option and fill all the details like Client number, Auth ID (Your preferred), Color and Auth ID description. And then save.

Now, once you created the Auth ID, you can proceed with Authorization Data folder. Double click on it and chose the newly created Auth ID.

Once you click continue the below screen will appear.

Click on the 'New Entries' and fill out the criteria. In the below example I have only added the T-code authorization logic. But one can add any type of standard or custom authorization objects available in the ERP system along with its Field Name and Value to get more accurate insight driven results and make the system more SoD Compliant. After filling out all the blanks & hit Save button,

After the critical authorizations are defined, the report can be run and the results (users/roles
having access to the defined critical authorizations) are shown on the screen.

Once you finish with all the above-mentioned steps, you need to go back to the Critical Authorization folder, where you have already created the custom variant. Select the variant and continue.

A blank screen will open. Click 'New Entries'

Now chose the Auth ID (which was created in table USCRAUTHID) from the search help area. Then save it. All the changes are recorded in a customizing TR. So, its better to use or track all the TR's generated while this activity.

Finally the Critical Authorization is ready for use. You can execute the report selecting the Critical Authorization by two way. You will get two selection criteria: User /Role. 

One can also merge multiple Critical Authorizations into Critical Combinations as per the business need.

 

Below are the technical Pre-requisites:

Whoever is defining or configuring this standard reports, should have access to below T-codes: 

  • SU_VCUSRVARCOM_DISP
  • SU_VCUSRVARCOM_CHAN
  • SU_VCUSRVAR_DISP
  • SU_VCUSRVAR_CHANGE

Below is the table structure and foreign key relationships of table USCRAUTHID

 

Thanks and regards,

Saikat Roy

RISE with SAP SAP S/4HANA #SoD

entry.title: Re: Company code splits
entry.content:
SAP generally recommends creating new organizational units (plants, sales orgs, purchasing orgs) when splitting company codes, rather than copying existing ones. Copying may save time initially but can lead to long-term data integrity, reporting, and configuration issues. SAP Note 1595808 supports this caution.

While many suggest copying to save effort, here are the key risks:

Shared Master Data Conflicts
Copied org units may retain links to the original company codeâ€™s master data (e.g., vendors, customers, materials), causing confusion or errors in transactions.

Reporting Ambiguity
Historical data may be difficult to segregate cleanly between the old and new company codes, complicating audits and financial reporting.

Configuration Overlap
Org units copied without proper reconfiguration may inherit settings (e.g., pricing procedures, account determination) that are inappropriate for the new company code.

Authorization Issues
Users may inadvertently gain access to data across both company codes due to shared org structures.

Future Scalability
Reusing org units can limit flexibility in future reorganizations, mergers, or divestitures.

SAP's recommended approach is to create new org units tailored to the new company codeâ€™s operational needs. Reconfigure master data and transactional settings to ensure clean separation. Use migration tools or data services to transfer relevant data (e.g., materials, vendors) with proper mapping and validation. Document the split thoroughly to support audit and compliance requirements.

entry.title: Re: Business rule trace for external onboarding users
entry.content:
@HarshaShet 

1.Create Rule Trace object with existing admin user

2.Export this Rule Trace from Import Export Data Tool. Select Include Dependencies and Select all data records as No. For Select objects dropdown select your Rule Trace object and click on Export

3.To get the exported Rule Trace -go to Scheduled Job Monitor look for MDF Data Export job type. Click on View Details and click on Download Status.

4.It would download a Zip file which has file with name Rule Trace.csv. Open Rule Trace.csv in Notepad++ or any other app but do not open in excel as it causes alignment issue leading to import failure.

Now in csv file replace admin user ID by new hire User ID save the file and update ZIP file.

Import:

1.Go to Import and Export Data, select Import Data select ZIP File tab and upload the updated ZIP file. Click on Import.

2.Go to Scheduled Job Monitor look for MDF Data Import job type. Click on View Details and see that Progress says that Passed : 1 and Failed : 0

3.Now Go to Manage Data and load your Rule Trace object and you can see that now the Login User is changed to new hire.

4.Now we have to external user visibility of this Rule Trace object. For this we need to add on Save rule to set External User Visibility to Yes. Before that we should enable the visibility of External User Visibility field on Rule Trace Object Definition to Read Only.

Go to Configure Object Definition > Select Object Definition > Select Rule Trace > Take Action > Edit .

mdfSystemExternalUserVisibility field > Click on Details > Select Visibility as Read Only. Save the Objects Definition

5.Now create On Save Rule as below and add it to the object definition and save again

 

if condition: always true

set ruletrace.extuservisibility equal to yes

 

Result :By this we would be able to access Rule Trace for logging.

entry.title: Re: Text Object cannot move to X=0 or Y=0 with Snap to Gr...
entry.content:
Hi Groovy,

Great post, nice to see info with details and test results...

As you know CR 2016 is end of life a year ago, so no chance to get it fixed, end of life info:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SUPPORT_CONTENT/crystalreports/3354088411.html?locale=en-US

I tested this in CR 2025 at 110% and I see the same thing, even using Size and Position did have problems:

It would move the Y but not the X, after viewing.

CR's formatting engine is very complex, it uses third party (Microsoft dependencies) and others:

USP10.dll

GDI.dll and GDIPlus.dll

Default printer properties, I tried setting No Printer (USP10) and my Lexmark laser printer (GDI), it did not make any difference.

I also tried setting it to .160 cm and 100% and it too does have issues, if you want to call it that...

I suspect this has always been this way so not likely anything R&D can do about it, it's all part of the complex formatting logic CR uses to place objects.

I'll let R&D know to have a look at this post but I don't expect there is much they can do to resolve the issue. It's basically a minor issue and too costly to look into.

Also note, with Microsoft updates, I am using Window 11 25H2, there have been a few formatting issues R&D is still working on and too complex to fix at this time.

Curious, are you reporting the issue because it's affecting your use or just noting the issue you discovered?

Bottom line is you know the limitations, so make a note when designing reports not to use those Zoom levels.

Don

entry.title: Object Dependency in Material Classification
entry.content:
Introduction

Object dependency refers as set of rules that are considered when classifying objects. The purpose of object dependency is to optimize and automate the classification process, that is, the characteristic value assignment. We can use object dependency to forbid specific value combinations, require a characteristic or set values for characteristics based on other selections.

Below table shows the differences between local and global object dependencies.

Global Object DependencyLocal Object Dependency
  • Available across the entire system, so they can be used by multiple objects or processes. 
  • Can be reused in different contexts wherever the same conditions or procedures are needed.
  • Promotes consistency and reduces redundancy when you have conditions or procedures that are common and applicable to multiple objects or scenarios.
  • Specific to a particular object or process and are not available for use where in the system.
  • Not designed for reuse outside the scope of the specific object or process they are tied to.
  • Use when the conditions or procedures are unique to a specific object or scenario allows for more concise and context-specific definitions without affecting other parts of the system.

In this blog, we will look at two types of object dependencies, which are Precondition and Selection condition. We will use material classification as our example. 

Below table shows the characteristics of bolt variants.

Pre-requisition:

  1. Create characteristics in Tcode CT04 or Manage Characteristics app.
  2. Create Class type 001, BOLT in Tcode CL01 or Create Classes app.
  3. Assign the characteristics created in step (1) to the Class type 001.
  4. Create SAP material codes for the bolt variants, M6 â€“ M16.
  5. Assign the class to the materials in Tcode CL24N or Manage Class Assignments app.

Precondition

Precondition object dependency type is used to temporarily forbid the value assignment of characteristics or use of characteristic values. 

Example 1,

Requirement: Coating Plain is only available for Tensile Strength <=400 MPa.

What to forbid: Value of CHARC COATING.

Where to assign Object Dependency: Value of CHARC COATING, Plain.

Syntax: TENSILE_STRENGTH<=400 Mpa.

1. Go to Tcode CT04 or Manage Characteristics app.

2. Go to Values tab and select the value Plain.

3. Go to Extras -> Object Dependencies -> Editor at the header.

  • Select Processing Mode as Classic.
  • Select Precondition radio button.

4. Key in the syntax or use Input Help (F4) button to build the syntax.

5. Select check button to check for any syntax error.

6. Save the error free syntax and the characteristic.

Thus, when assigning object to class in Tcode CL24N or Manage Class Assignments app, we can see that the coating Plain is not available when Tensile Strength > 400 Mpa.

However, coating Plain is available when Tensile Strength = 400 MPa.

There will be inconsistency if CHARC value Plain is used when Tensile Strength >400 Mpa and the screen canâ€™t be saved.

Selection Condition

Selection condition object dependency type is used to make characteristics dynamic as required characteristics.

Example 2,

Requirement: CHARC MATERIAL_TYPE is a required characteristic when CHARC MATERIAL is valuated as Carbon Steel.

What becomes a required characteristic: CHARC MATERIAL_TYPE

Where to assign Object Dependency: CHARC MATERIAL_TYPE.

Syntax: MATERIAL = â€˜Carbon Steel'

1. Go to Tcode CT04 or Manage Characteristics app.

2. Entry is not required for CHARC MATERIAL_TYPE.

3. Go to Extras -> Object Dependencies -> Editor at the header in change mode.

  • Select Processing Mode as Classic.
  • Select Selection condition radio button.

4. Key in the syntax or use Input Help (F4) button to build the syntax.

5. Select check button to check for any syntax error.

6. Save the error free syntax and the characteristic.

Thus, when assigning object to class in Tcode CL24N or Manage Class Assignments app, we can see that system hits error if try to save without valuating CHARC MATERIAL_TYPE when CHARC MATERIAL is valuated as Carbon Steel.

However, the screen still can be saved but classification status will be changed to 3, Incomplete.

In conclusion, we can see object dependency is a powerful tool which can be used to automate the classification process.

entry.title: Expiring Price Handling Powered by Joule
entry.content:
The Joule capability "Expiring Price Handling" has been released in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2502.3. This blog introduces this feature in detail, so that you can interact with Joule smoothly and manage expiring prices efficiently. 

 

Overview

You can ask Joule to fetch prices (stored as condition records for pricing in sales in the system) that will expire soon. For expiring prices, Joule can help renew them by extending their validity periods and adjusting the condition amounts or ratios according to your requirements. After you confirm to extend the expiring prices, a price renewal background job will be created. You can also check the progress and result of the price renewal job via Joule.

Figure 1

Please check out the following help document and demo for a glimpse.

    • Help Document: Renew Expiring Prices
    • Demo: Renew Product Prices with Joule

 

Feature in Details

 

Definition of "Expiring Price"

Before using this feature, it's important to understand what qualifies as an "Expiring Price". Joule retrieves prices that expire between the current date and the given date (including both dates) without a successor record. Only records without a successor are considered "Expiring".

  • Case 1 and 2: Prices without a successor --> considered "expiring". 
  • Case 3: Even if its Valid-To date falls between the current date and the given date, it has a successor with a continuous validity period starting right after its Valid-To date --> not considered "expiring".
  • Case 4: Already expired prices --> not considered "expiring".

Figure 2

Note that, this feature only retrieves/renews the prices approaching expiration (meaning still valid for the time being), but cannot fetch/renew the prices which are already expired (Case 4 above).

 

How Are Expiring Prices Renewed?

Instead of updating the original Valid-To date of the expiring price, Joule creates a new continuous validity period for the expiring price (with Valid-From date set to the date one day after the Valid-To date of the expiring price). Optionally, the new validity period could have a new condition amount/ratio. The purpose of this is to keep the existing "Expiring Price" unchanged, but create its successor only.

Do take note that, the new validity being created could possibly overlap with the existing validity that lies in future, such as the Case 2 above. Assume that the gap between the expiring price and its future validity is 9 months long. If we extend the validity period of the expiring price by 1 year, the new validity and existing future validity will overlap for 3 months. In this case, the new validity will overwrite the existing validity during the overlapped period.

 

Always Start from "Show Expiring Prices"

You can activate the "Expiring Price Handling" feature by talking to Joule with phrases like below:

  • "Show me prices for sales organization 1710 that expire before December 31, 2025."
  • "List the prices with condition type PPR0 that are expiring before Dec 31, 2025."
  • "Are there any prices for condition type PPR0 and sales organization 1010 expiring before December 31, 2025?"

Even if you ask Joule to extend the expiring price directly, you will be redirected to show expiring prices, because the extension/renewal could only be performed on the expiring prices already listed in Joule.

Figure 3

Expiration date is a mandatory for querying expiring prices. If the date is not given, Joule will prompt you to provide one, so that it can proceed to search for the expiring prices.

Figure 4

For best results, include at least one of the following filters in your query. Currently, these are the only fields supported as the filter.

  • Condition type
  • Sales organization
  • Distribution channel
  • Product
  • Customer
  • Customer project ID
 
Expiration Urgency Level

The expiring prices will be listed and sorted by urgency:

  • Red:  â‰¤30 days left before expiration
  • Orange:  31~60 days left before expiration
  • Green:  >60 days left before expiration

Figure 5

 

Dynamic Grouping

At the time this blog is being written, Joule can display up to 30 prices per message. If more than 30 expiring prices are found, they will be grouped dynamically,  for example:

  • By condition type + sales org. + urgency level.
  • By condition type + urgency level.
  • By urgency level only.

This ensures the total number of groups is kept â‰¤30.

Figure 6

 

Check Price Renewal Job Log

After clicking "Confirm" to extend prices, a mass creation job will be created in the background to create the new validity periods. You can check progress and result of the renewal job by clicking the "Check Progress" button. The job result is summarized in a card format. You can click "Open in App" to navigate to the "Manage Prices - Sales" app to check the details of the job.

Figure 7

Alternatively, you can also go to "Manage Prices - Sales" app --> click "Monitor Imports and Jobs" at the upper-right corner. --> switch to "Scheduled Jobs" tab. All the previously created jobs are listed, including the mass creation job created from "Manage Prices - Sales" app. Note that the price renewal jobs created via Joule are always named "Price Renewal xxxxxxxxxxxxxx".

Figure 8

 

Limitations

Instability of Resolving Expiration Date

If you ask Joule to show the prices expiring in N months/days, Joule may occasionally resolve the expiration date incorrectly. This can lead to an inaccurate or empty results. This is because the current LLMs do not inherently have awareness of real-time information.

Thus, we recommend providing specific dates to Joule, such as "Show me prices that are going to expire before 31 Dec, 2025" or "List prices due to expire on 31/03/2026".

 

Short Request Timeout

There's a short request timeout (only 15 seconds) imposed by Joule on any API call to backend. If you don't provide any filter criteria, you may encounter a timeout.

Figure 9

Therefore, always include at least one of the supported filters while asking Joule to show the expiring prices.
